question: When acids released by trees change soil chemistry, what type of weathering is occurring?

content.source_1: Chemical weathering includes the dissolution and alteration of minerals by acids; organic acids released by roots and microbes can dissolve iron-bearing minerals and oxides, liberating Fe into soil solution.
content.source_2: Acidification of the rhizosphere increases the solubility of Fe(III) oxides/hydroxides; their dissolution by organic acids is a classic example of chemical weathering in soils.
content.source_3: Many trees (Strategy I plants) acquire iron by releasing protons to acidify the rhizosphere and using ferric-chelate reductase at the root surface to reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+ for uptake; this acts chiefly on soluble or exchangeable Fe without degrading mineral lattices.
content.source_4: In soil science, ion exchange occurs when H+ displaces cations (including Fe) from clay and organic matter exchange sites; ion exchange does not alter mineral structure and is not classified as weathering.
content.source_5: Iron chlorosis produces yellowing leaves even in iron-rich soils because Fe is present in forms that are poorly available to roots; availability depends on chemical form, pH, and complexation.
content.source_6: Siderophore/phytosiderophore chelation mobilizes ferric iron by forming soluble complexes in the rhizosphere, enhancing availability through complexation rather than by dissolving the parent mineral structure.
